Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: The mandatory daily pre-work safety briefing is starting in two minutes.
Expectation2: Represent clients effectively in legal proceedings
Situation2: They appear at a minor hearing where the stakes are relatively low
Story: I wipe the sweat from my brow, glancing at the clock above the site office. Two minutes until the safety briefing. The foreman expects everyone there, no exceptions—especially after last week’s near-miss. I can’t afford to let the team down or risk my job. But my phone buzzes in my pocket, and I see the reminder: minor hearing, courthouse, ten minutes. My client’s case isn’t high stakes, but they’re counting on me to show up, to speak for them. I promised I’d be there. My boots are caked with mud, my hands rough from hauling rebar, but my mind is already in the courtroom, rehearsing arguments. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in—my crew’s trust, my client’s hope. I can’t be in two places at once. My heart pounds as I stand at the crossroads, torn between the hard hats and the courtroom benches, knowing someone will be let down no matter what I choose.
